Reaffirming: http://www.politico.eu/article/turkey-to-miss-visa-free-travel-deadline/ Turkey will miss an end of June deadline to meet the EU’s conditions for securing visa-free travel to the bloc for its citizens, the European Commission is to confirm Wednesday. Visa liberalization was a key part of an EU-Turkey deal struck in March in which Ankara was asked to stem the flow of refugees into Europe in exchange for cash and other benefits. The number of migrants reaching Europe through Turkey has dropped to almost zero since the deal came into effect. Part of the deal was to speed up the lifting of “visa requirements for Turkish citizens at the latest by the end of June 2016” — the original deadline was October — but only if Turkey met all the outstanding conditions, or so-called benchmarks. The June deadline is now going to be missed, with a Commission official saying “there were no major developments on the benchmarks.” The next report on Ankara’s progress, the official said, is due in September. Turkey has had its sights set on September for some time. “We won’t be able to meet the initial [June] deadline but will probably meet the next one,” said a Turkish official, adding “we are closer to an understanding on completing the … remaining benchmarks.” The road ahead is still long, however.

Geopolitically, this deal has significant implications. One the one hand, Merkel certainly will  not "cave in" by 1/7/16 resolution deadline date. Obvious reasons.  On the other hand, such scenario has an extremely high probability over the next few months.  Why?  First, for arguments sake, assume  Brexit Leave victory. No longer far fetched. Second, a summer & fall  of EU political chaos &, a further rise NON STATUS QUO sentiment already firmly established throughout Europe. Think political dispersion to the Far Right in France, Austria, AfD in Germany, &, Eastern Europe. The v/ LAST THING Brussels needs at this stage of its stop & go from crisis to crisis politically existence.  Erdogan has the equivalent of a human weapon in his hands in the form of refugees presently under Turkish control.  His human rights track record history is more than clear ( mildly put)! Expect Merkel & the EU, over the next few months to resurrect a wishy-washy, vague verbiage agreement w/ Erdogan that attempts to save face on all sides while leaving the real losers ( the tsunami of refugees there already & more on their way from Aleppo, Mosul & elsewhere) as...continued real losers who in this Trojan Horse transaction b/w the Turks & the EU. http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/06/12/merkel-ready-to-cave-to-turkish-pressure-on-visas-british-diplom/ "...The visa waiver deal had been due to kick in on July 1, and there were fears that Erdogan would increase migrant flows if he did not get his way.

Terror laws an insurmountable hurdle, in the short term at least.
The EU is flaccid and unable of enforcing anything that will anger a large number of its members. And carrying through on this would do so.

For many reasons it is not likely at all:
1) It would compromise the Remain campaign in the upcoming referendum on UK remaining in the EU. In case of a victory of the leavers, EU would face a political catastrophe, it's quite likely that such kind of outcome would damage and destabilize the EU substantially. Even if the lift doesn't lead to a victory of "leave", it would definitely cause an ongoing hostile migration-debate which could severely damage the relationship between EU and UK.
2) Apart from the Leave-Remain-campaign in UK: A lift of those requirements would cause major discussions with Eastern & Central European states which are opposing this lift. Even if the governments would support the lift, it would cause domestic problems for those states and might be a source of political instability (e.g. in Germany it could lead to an open challenge of Angela Merkel by the right wing of the conservative party and by CSU and support the rise of AfD).
3) Such lift would directly challenge the core principles of EU since they would need to ignore there own rules in order to lift visa requirements for Turkish citizens.
4) It's questionable if Erdogan is really intending to cause major problems if there is no lift, Turkey (and he himself) would have much to loose and it's also not said that EU doesn't find another way of solving the refugee-crisis (he would just have the power to force EU to such a lift, if it is certain that there is no other way of controlling the crisis than working with Turkey in that way).

Angela Merkel said more time was needed to agree on Turkey’s visa-free travel to the European Union. A breakdown in talks could mean Turkey stops co-operating in curbing migrant flows

Maybe Western European engineers who for no other reason like Germany, but it is errant for Germans to believe, after these years, that more Western Europeans  than Turks are arriving for work in Germany. The article leads with Germany's statement, not Brussels, and asks without asking, which view is more important? Turks won't get EU visa waiver before 2017: Bild newspaper
http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/Default.aspx The German government does not expect Turks to get visa-free entry into the European Union before 2017 because Ankara will not fulfil the conditions for that by the end of this year, newspaper Bild cited sources in Berlin as saying on May 23.  Turkey and the EU have been discussing visa liberalisation since 2013 and agreed in March to press ahead with it as part of a deal to stop the flow of illegal migrants from Turkey to the EU. EU officials and diplomats say the EU is set to miss an end-June deadline due to a dispute over Turkish anti-terrorism law.  A spokeswoman for the German government could not immediately comment on the report.  Turkey's government says it has already met the EU's criteria for visa-free travel.  A Forsa poll for German newspaper Handelsblatt showed that almost two-thirds of Germans disagree with the EU-Turkey deal that Chancellor Angela Merkel spearheaded efforts to secure as her popularity waned due to her liberal migrant policy.  Asked in a Forsa poll for German newspaper Handelsblatt "Do you think Merkel's Turkey politics are right?" 59 percent said 'no' while 31 percent said 'yes'.  The survey showed that 44 percent of Germans want Merkel to remain chancellor after a 2017 national election while 47 percent do not.  While some politicians have suggested the influx of migrants could be a solution to a skilled labour shortage in Germany, most Germans are not convinced: asked whether they thought the majority of refugees could be integrated into the German labour market, 56 percent said 'no' and 38 percent 'yes'.  The poll of 1,002 people was carried out on May 17-18.

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-europe-migrants-eu-turkey-idUSKCN0YA1E9 "The European Union is set to miss an end-June deadline to grant visa-free travel to Turkey because of a dispute over Turkish anti-terrorism law, barring an improbable sudden concession by President Tayyip Erdogan, EU officials and diplomats say. "The main reward for Ankara's collaboration in choking off an influx of migrants into Europe may now come at the earliest in July but more likely not until the autumn, they say.
. . . 
"Allowing Turks to visit Europe's 26-nation Schengen area visa-free for up to three months is unpopular in many EU states, including France, where authorities fear it could be a gift to anti-immigration populist Marine Le Pen in elections next year. "Ankara has yet to meet five of the 72 requirements for visa liberalization, according to the executive European Commission, which proposed this month relaxing travel rules for Turks if Turkey fulfilled those benchmarks by the end of June. But the European Parliament, which must approve the visa decision, has refused to start work on the proposal until Ankara meets the criteria in full. Parliament President Martin Schulz said he did not see that happening before the end of June. "De facto a decision in June is not possible anymore," said an EU source familiar with the negotiations. Lawmakers could still theoretically vote on the plan at their final plenary session on July 4-7, but more likely after the summer break. "Erdogan's main priority is to change the constitution to secure extensive presidential rule and he has said October would also be acceptable for visa liberalization. "An October scenario is possible, but also July. Let's see how the Turks comply," another EU source said. "Meanwhile, Turkey continues to stop migrants leaving its shores and both sides have a vital interest in keeping the deal alive. "The EU says Turkey must narrow its definition of terrorist crimes, which leads to extensive application of the law against intellectuals, Kurdish sympathizers and critics of Erdogan, including dozens of journalists and academics. Turkey has repeatedly declined to do so, saying the law is crucial to its fight with Kurdish and Islamic State militants. "The EU is now waiting to see what a new government will do on the outstanding criteria after a meeting of the ruling AK Party on Sunday picks a new prime minister, diplomats said. "We've been through this before," said another EU official with long experience of negotiating with Ankara. "It's not the first time there has been quite provocative talk from the Turkish side, then we sat down and found a way forward." "Sources in Brussels stress that the Commission's report said Turkey should "better align" - rather than "fully align" - its counter-terrorism regulation with EU norms, including to bring in more proportionality in punishment for any violations. That offers room for compromise.
. . . 
"The EU also promised revitalized EU accession talks and an initial 3 billion euros in aid for Syrian refugees in Turkey in return for Ankara's help on migration, and it has taken steps recently to speed up disbursement. "Turkey is only due to start issuing the advanced biometric passports required for visa-free travel in October. No Turks yet have the new generation of passports, EU officials say. "Given the European Parliament's tough stance on human rights and public anxiety in several EU states about granting visa-free entry to a largely Muslim population of 79 million, the room for compromise is limited. "We've got to get something that is more than a symbolic gesture from them on terrorism. The market will demand it," the first EU source said.

The German chancellor visits Istanbul on Sunday, ostensibly for a humanitarian summit but also for damage-control. Angela Merkel needs Turkey’s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, to stay reasonable and stick to his deal with the EU to keep refugees from crossing to Greece. He needs her too: above all, to get the EU to honour its promise to let Turks visit without visas. But there the symbiosis ends. Mr Erdogan wants a German satirist prosecuted for a poem that accused him, among other things, of goat-molestation. It may happen; free-speech advocates are appalled. Politicians from all parties want Germany to be firmer. A big diplomatic clash looms on June 2nd, when lawmakers will pass a resolution terming the Ottoman mass-killing of Armenians “genocide”. Mr Erdogan is outraged already. It won’t be an easy weekend for Mrs Merkel as she tries to salvage her most important, and most troubled, international relationship
---------

Cautiously optimistic language appears, increasingly, in some general commentaries and in at least one "visa liberalisation" press release from the European Parliament. While earlier (i.e., March 2016) reports featured significant pessimistic rhetoric, these seem linked moreso - functionally - to government leadership-related and human rights-related bias. Human rights violations appear to drive the process toward appeasement more directly than political disparagement. The international legal complex, in other words, seems compromised by the EU's own sense of [dis]unity and some of its members' opportunistic agendas. Ultimately, the EU could feel international pressure to accommodate refugees despite grassroots sentiments to the contrary. My positive forecast is tempered, however, by anti-dictatorship, anti-corruption sentiment and ongoing internal tensions in Turkey, Greece and Syria.

The 72 requirements needed to meet compliance by Turkey is not possible by then. The EU needs 65% of its voting bloc to agree, the countries that have the most voting power could request the previous voting rule which falls under this measure:
The previous qualified majority rule A qualified majority could debate the issue. Until 31 March 2017, member states can still request to use the previous rule for qualified majority voting. Under this rule, each member state representative has a certain number of votes, as set out in the EU treaties. The weighting of votes roughly reflects the size of population of each member state. The 352 votes are distributed as follows: France, Germany, Italy, United Kingdom: 29 votes each
Spain, Poland: 27 votes each
Romania: 14 votes
Netherlands: 13 votes
Belgium, Czech Republic, Greece, Hungary, Portugal: 12 votes each
Austria, Bulgaria, Sweden: 10 votes each
Croatia, Denmark, Ireland, Lithuania, Slovakia, Finland: 7 votes each
Cyprus, Estonia, Latvia, Luxembourg, Slovenia: 4 votes each
Malta: 3 votes
Under this previous rule, a qualified majority is reached in the Council if the following conditions are met: a majority of member states - 15 member states - vote in favour
a minimum of 260 votes out of the total 352 votes are cast in favour
A member state may ask for confirmation that the votes in favour represent at least 62% of the total EU population. If this is found not to be the case, the decision will not be adopted. http://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/council-eu/voting-system/qualified-majority/ As you know, whether they select the old or new voting law, a number of these countries are pressured by the Right to stop migration and a number of their mainstream leaders have moved to the right to stop their voters from going to the far right. As in Austria, the voters tens to support the far Right over the mainstream parties.  There are enough Euro-Skeptics in France, Belgium, Netherlands, Germany, UK, etc., to slow the migration and the Schengen Agreement.  I have discussed in earlier forecasts why the EU was DOA based on the weaknesses of their defense, agriculture, banking, and migration agreements or lack of structural enforcement., which was hidden in plain site prior to Euro Day and thereafter with the No votes winning on the EU Constitution referendum in the Netherlands and France. In France, it was more of a rural versus urban vote, where the rural areas wanted to punish Paris on it agricultural treaties. But this tension is not a French issue, but an example of why the EU is not in lock step on goals. What the EU and EP want, is not what people expected from them, which was that having their cake and eating it too was possible. Some key points:
1.   "I have no illusions that what we agreed today will be accompanied by further setbacks. There are big legal challenges that we must now overcome," Merkel said after the 28 EU leaders concluded the deal = there are uncertainties already!
2.   Under the pact, Ankara would take back all migrants and refugees, including Syrians, who cross to Greece illegally across the sea. In return, the EU would take in thousands of Syrian refugees directly from Turkey and reward it with more money, early visa-free travel and faster progress in EU membership talks = EU Memberships talks have been going on for many years......
3.   Ankara's central objective -- visa-free travel for Turks to Europe by June -- would still depend on Turkey meeting 72 long-standing EU criteria = Those 72 long-standing criteria have been what blocked the talks on point 2.
4. Turkey's four-decade-old dispute with Cyprus had been a key stumbling block. Cypriot President Nicos Anastasiades insisted there could be no opening of new "chapters" in Turkey's EU talks until Ankara de facto recognizes the Cypriot state = This is yet another block on the road.
5.  Turkey's human rights record has drawn mounting criticism amid a crackdown on Kurdish separatists, arrests of critical journalists and the seizure of its best-selling newspaper = and this is another critical point

There are currently 5 remaining hurdles/benchmarks that Turkey must meet in order to qualify for the visa liberalization. (http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-36246807) Of these, the European Commission states that "2 benchmarks... could not objectively be completed in the given timeframe," which were the implementation of biometric passports and "implementing the provisions of the EU-Turkey readmission agreement." (http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_MEMO-16-1625_en.htm) Regardless, the Commission still "acknowledges the good progress made by the Turkish authorities so far, and encourages them to step up these efforts in order to meet all requirements in order to obtain visa liberalisation by the end of June." Turkey's president Erdogan was recently quoted as saying "We'll go our way, you go yours" in response to the continued demand to meet the benchmarks, specifically the redefinition of terrorism. (http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-36229468) The visa proposal will not reach committee (http://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/news-room/20160509IPR26368/Visa-liberalisation-for-Turkey-EU-criteria-must-be-met-say-MEPs) until all the requirements are met, and it doesn't seem like Turkey is playing ball.  All in all, I think Turkey has most of the bargaining chips, as the EU desperately wants to reduce the refugees entering from Turkey. If Turkey's president (who recently gained more power after the resignation of Turkey's PM) isn't willing to accept the conditions of the program, I don't see how the EU Parliament and the Council would agree to lift the visa requirements. I think a good way to get a numerical number would be counting up votes in the Council, seeing what each country's leader thinks of the Turkey proposal. Short of that, I'm just going with a low, but still significant chance that either a)Erdogan changes his mind (less likely) or b)the EU eases its benchmarks (more likely).

There are several key requirements that still need to be fulfilled by Turkey. They seem to be difficult challenges to overcome by June. I've listed some of the remaining issues below. (I assume that if Turkey cannot accomplish the multiple key elements by July, then the EU and Turkey will set another deadline. It seems that they both want to make the agreement happen, even if it takes longer than anticipated.) According to the EU Second progress report March 2016: http://ec.europa.eu/dgs/home-affairs/e-library/documents/policies/international-affairs/general/docs/turkey_second_progress_report_en.pdf BLOCK 1: DOCUMENT SECURITY
Turkey should start issuing passports with a contactless chip which includes not only the facial image of the holder, but also the holder’s fingerprints BLOCK 2: MIGRATION MANAGEMENT
The most important of the requirements which remain to be fulfilled is related to Turkey's need to "Carry out adequate border checks and border surveillance […] in such a manner that it will cause a significant and sustained reduction of the number of persons managing to illegally cross the Turkish borders either for entering or for exiting Turkey". (BTW- Isn't this the central point of the agreement between EU and Turkey, so if Turkey cannot do more to control the refugee flow, what is the point of the visa agreement??) BLOCK 3: PUBLIC ORDER AND SECURITY
.....the implementation of the requirements of block 3 remains considerably less advanced than blocks 1 and 2. ...Start implementing the Council of Europe Convention for the Protection of Individuals with regard to Automatic Processing of Personal Data of 1981, and ratify its Additional Protocol (CETS n° 181). Adopt legislation on the protection of personal data in line with the EU and the Council of Europe standards; ...start implementing the recently ratified Council of Europe Convention on Laundering, Search, Seizure and Confiscation of the Proceeds from Crime and on the Financing of Terrorism (CETS n°198) and bring the Turkish national legislative framework in this area in line with the standards set by this Convention; BLOCK 4: FUNDAMENTAL RIGHTS
revise Turkish legislation on terrorism with the aim of aligning it with the EU acquis, the Council of Europe standards and with the European Court of Human Rights (ECtHR) jurisprudence on terrorism;...ratify Protocols 4 and 7 to the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR), or, alternatively, ensure or demonstrate that equivalent provisions are included into the Turkish legal framework; BLOCK 5: READMISSION OF IRREGULAR MIGRANTS
start applying and effectively implement, with regard to all Member States, the provisions of the EU-Turkey Readmission Agreement related to third-country nationals, which Turkey has committed to do as of 1 June 2016;...improve the implementation of the already applicable provisions of the EU-Turkey readmission agreement related to return and readmission of its own nationals and stateless persons, which at present are not enforced in a systematic manner by all Turkish diplomatic missions.
